thread.title: Twitter takes on Oscars' best picture snafu
thread.title_full: Twitter takes on Oscars' best picture snafu - CNN.com

author: Madison Park
title: Twitter takes on Oscars' best picture snafu
text:
Story highlights "La La Land" was accidentally announced as the winner, when "Moonlight" had won Social media digs at the snafu (CNN) The biggest blunder at the Oscars became instant social media gold. 
At first, "La La Land" was announced as the best picture after presenter Warren Beatty appeared baffled by what was on the card. Co-presenter Faye Dunaway glanced at the card and announced the winner as "La La Land." A flurry of confusion unfolded onstage as the cast and crew of "La La Land" -- in the middle of their acceptance speeches -- realized the real winner was "Moonlight." Twitter users posted their interpretation of what happened. #Oscars pic.twitter.com/p0Lb5DbzG0 
â€” Nathan Ournâ„¢ğŸ”±ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡­ (@Nxthann_) February 27, 2017 Hey "La La Land" remember when you gave us that fake happy ending and then took it away

How's it feel
â€” Daniel "Kibblesmith" (@kibblesmith) February 27, 2017 "We rob #Oscars " pic.twitter.com/7G5Yx53u9Z 
â€” Will McKinley (@willmckinley) February 27, 2017 "This is very unfortunate what happened," host Jimmy Kimmel quipped. "Personally, I blame Steve Harvey for this." Read More He was referring to the famous incident in which host Steve Harvey announced the wrong Miss Universe winner in 2015. The cast of "Moonlight" and "La La Land" appear on stage as presenter Warren Beatty shows the winner's envelope for Best Movie "Moonlight" on stage. Then, the Internet took over on the shocking moment. MY FACE RN. ğŸ‘ğŸ½ğŸ‘ğŸ½ğŸ‘ğŸ½ğŸ‘ğŸ½ #Moonlight #Oscars pic.twitter.com/ZpDWllX0HA 
â€” bÌ¶. (@heresbaely) February 27, 2017 "Have your people call our people -- we know what to do," tweeted the verified Miss Universe account. Have your people call our people - we know what to do. #Oscars #MissUniverse 
â€” Miss Universe (@MissUniverse) February 27, 2017 The comparison to Harvey's gaffe was inevitable. Warren Beatty just became the new host of FAMILY FEUD. #Oscars 
â€” Patton Oswalt (@pattonoswalt) February 27, 2017 Steve Harvey tonight. via @EbrojiApp #Oscars #Moonlight #LaLaLand pic.twitter.com/MpSO9lhnAZ 
â€” jesse Williams. (@iJesseWilliams) February 27, 2017 Maybe this wasn't an actual blunder, hypothesized some viewers. Perhaps this was just a shocking plot twist directed by M. Night Shyamalan. the oscars, directed by m night shyamalan
â€” Bob Vulfov (@bobvulfov) February 27, 2017 The director responded to the theory. I wrote the ending of the academy awards 2017. @jimmykimmel we really got them!
â€” M. Night Shyamalan (@MNightShyamalan) February 27, 2017 Of course, political jokes ensued. Warren Beatty and #FayeDunaway just announced Hillary Clinton has in fact won the election!!! #BestPicture #Oscars #FakeNews #FakeAwards 
â€” Cenk Uygur (@cenkuygur) February 27, 2017 You know what the problem is -- millions of Academy members voted illegally.
â€” Seth MacFarlane (@SethMacFarlane) February 27, 2017 Guarantee there will be more investigation into the #Oscars2017 #BestPicture mixup than #Russia 's interference in our election. #Oscars 
â€” aasif mandvi (@aasif) February 27, 2017 Some smelled a perfect marketing opportunity. Get the name wrong? We offer 24hr grace periods to correct minor errors. So you won't be left in La La Land. #Oscars https://t.co/OJfTN8vOrA pic.twitter.com/NVtD9TDeB3 
â€” Ryanair (@Ryanair) February 27, 2017 It wasn't such a golden opportunity for PriceWaterHouseCoopers, though. I feel sorry for anyone having Price Waterhouse Coopers preparing their taxes
â€” Dave Itzkoff (@ditzkoff) February 27, 2017 Regardless of how it unfolded Sunday night, some tweeted how groundbreaking it was for "Moonlight" to take the top prize. Nothing that happened on the stage should overshadow the major achievement of #Moonlight winning #BestPicture at the #Oscars tonight. pic.twitter.com/4S9bv9kUkI 
â€” Keith Boykin (@keithboykin) February 27, 2017 STILL SPEECHLESS pic.twitter.com/qe3NUDWAHM 
â€” Barry Jenkins (@BandryBarry) February 27, 2017 Its director, Barry Jenkins, tweeted the correct card for best picture.
